website_summaries.verdict: Fills an important niche in the weightlifting field, with key information for older lifters, but could stand to bulk up its training and nutrition sections.
pros: A fast read, well-edited, and concise
Includes basic lifting info for beginners and novices just learning power lifting
Engaging, supportive commentary on starting or continuing in the sport
cons: Somewhat lacking in age-specific instruction for lifters above intermediate skill
Could bulk up its nutrition section
Supplemental lifting texts may be needed by some

customer_reviews.title: A Must for Older Weightlifters
customer_reviews.text: I am very new to weightlifting, so this books been a godsend. It is very well-organized and full of great information written in an accessible way. The information on warming up and mobility is detailed and easy to follow. A few weeks after reading and incorporating the information, I have made great progress on my lifts and have been achieving PRs- injury-free. This book combined with "Starting Strength" have made me more confident in my training. I highly recommend this to any older weightlifters- especially those who are new to the sport.
customer_reviews.author: TalkShop99

customer_reviews.title: Nice talk for "aging" lifters
customer_reviews.text: Actually a nice little pep talk through "aging" in a testosterone dominated sport. It's ok not to be able to lift 2x your body weight after 40 yrs. sometimes we need to be reminded of that. Good guidelines and workout patterns (I won't say fully developed programs) for lifting heavy for life. Enjoyed it.
customer_reviews.author: Zarreff

customer_reviews.title: Audience Well Targeted
customer_reviews.text: As a novice and masters weightlifter I was at a loss until I found this book. It was extremely helpful. It is a must have especially for newbies to the sport. Matt Foreman is straight up. No fancy stuff just right to the point. This is truly one of my most valuable books in my gym.
customer_reviews.author: AJ Borja

customer_reviews.title: Great masters lifting book
customer_reviews.text: I really enjoyed his thoughts on aging while continuing weightlifting. I especially appreciated the programming musings he provided not only by the author but by other notables in weightlifting. It really helped me to feel comfortable listening to my body while remaining hopeful that I can be competitive in masters lifting.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Gave realistic training program examples for Master athletes.
customer_reviews.text: Good read. Very informative. Geared towards beginner and experienced lifters alike. Gave a lot if training examples as well as what to expect as an older lifter.
customer_reviews.author: Samir

customer_reviews.title: Must Read For Master's Lifters (And Their Coaches!)
customer_reviews.text: I'm a 53 year old who recently took up Master's Weightlifting. This book is one of the only books I've ever seen directed towards Master's athletes. The author is well-respected in the Olympic lifting community and provides practical hands-on advice about how to enter the sport and how to improve. I thoroughly enjoyed the profiles of ten Master's lifters. I highly recommend this book to both Master's athletes and their coaches.
customer_reviews.author: jt kalnay

customer_reviews.title: A Must Have For Every Weightlifter Over 30!
customer_reviews.text: I read this book from cover to cover and I have to say, Matt Foreman has a way of delivering quality information in an easy to read and entertaining manner. Some of the one-liners are hysterical but the greatest value comes from some of the golden weightlifting nuggets that the book contains. His vast weightlifting experience, as well as the experience of other Master's lifters serves as an invaluable resource for any Master's weightlifter, whether competitive or recreational. I have an extensive library of Olympic weightlifting books and this is the only one that addresses the concerns and circumstances of the Master's age weightlifter. It is a must buy, and is well worth the investment!
customer_reviews.author: Weightlifting Doc

customer_reviews.title: A MUST READ for Masters Lifters
customer_reviews.text: Great book. Excellent technical coaching for the Masters Olympic or Power lifter. Masters - if you're like me and are having trouble recovering from workouts and healing from injuries - you need to read this!!!
customer_reviews.author: Double Ott Rancher

customer_reviews.title: Smart Lifting
customer_reviews.text: Great book if your a Master lifted wanting to make a come back
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Very clever and engaging author with great sense of humor. Obviously knows his craft.
customer_reviews.author: Super T

customer_reviews.title: Quality Product!
customer_reviews.text: Written by the true master! I've been reading Matt's articles for a few years now and he knows his stuff. Written in Matt's humorous voice, this book is very easy to read and very hard to put down! The technical aspects as well as the life lessons are shared throughout. This is a wonderful resource for the skilled or the first-time Master Lifter. I'm buying a second copy to share with my coach as I'm the only Master he works with and I always knew I was different. Quality product!
customer_reviews.author: Meg Freeman

customer_reviews.title: very well suited for the intended audience!
customer_reviews.text: This book is an excellent introduction master weightlifting. It is motivating, and carefully addresses the issues separating geezers from those young, potential top-notch, athletes most coaches wants to work with. The section on learning the lifts is good -good enough for a beginner. The section on programming is superb, and well suited for ailing geezers with sleep deficits, cortisol surplus, and unruly kids.
customer_reviews.author: The Unemployed Economist

customer_reviews.title: A guide for the older Olympic lifter on how to ...
customer_reviews.text: A guide for the older Olympic lifter on how to continue to train well and safely despite advancing age and the issues that may present.
customer_reviews.author: Bruce Kelly

customer_reviews.title: Great Perspective
customer_reviews.text: I am new to weight lifting, but fortunately was recommended this book. This is a must read for Master lifters. Great Perspective and outlook:
customer_reviews.author: Brian T. Lamb

customer_reviews.title: I am a new master lifter and was looking for ...
customer_reviews.text: I am a new master lifter and was looking for some depth in analysing the lifts and more ideas on techniques to improve. Found the book a bit light.
customer_reviews.author: Michael Cooper

customer_reviews.title: An Innvaluable Source fof Masters Weightlifters
customer_reviews.text: Matt Foreman has written an excellent guide to Olympic Weightlifting for Masters Athletes. His comprehensive approach covers everything from the philosophical and psychological approach to lifting in later life, to the nuts and bolts of training. I particularly liked his interviews of other lifters, providing a broader view of the sport from those who have been lifting for many years.
customer_reviews.author: Tom Jones

customer_reviews.title: Well Done
customer_reviews.text: Excellent work for those of us that are mere mortals that still want to improve. It is a great mix of realism, pragmatic advice and optimism.
customer_reviews.author: Raymond Trotta

customer_reviews.title: A great read with some great programming tips!
customer_reviews.text: A great book written for older folks in the OLY lifting game. I'm a 40 year old lifter with 25 years of experience, and it was good to know and read that other people have success with lifting only 2-3 days per week. Matt has a fun yet informative writing style that I enjoyed reading about. Matt has some great information about how to warm up, and the programs that he has used as he aged to some very successful lifting. I'm looking forward to reading some of his other works!
customer_reviews.author: Kory Mac

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: No problems on what has been received . Total satisfaction.
customer_reviews.author: Robert S. Danilovich

customer_reviews.title: Definitely the best book intended for the master weightlifter
customer_reviews.text: Definitely the best book intended for the master weightlifter. It gave answers to many questions I had a master lifter. Would certainly recommend this book for all weightlifters to read. Thank you Matt Foreman!!!
customer_reviews.author: Louie Uribe

customer_reviews.title: ... coach and I find this book to be a great read for any avid lifter beginner or advanced to ...
customer_reviews.text: I'm a strength coach and I find this book to be a great read for any avid lifter beginner or advanced to see different training programs of successful athletes especially as we age.
customer_reviews.author: Dustin R.

customer_reviews.title: Excellent book, easy reading and entertaining too.
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic book that clearly focuses on the unique problems concerning older lifters that still wish to continue to train and compete. Must read for anyone in that group, or training anyone in that group.
customer_reviews.author: Neil Kanterman

customer_reviews.title: Your own personal trainer 24/7
customer_reviews.text: Good information for lifters not quite so young anymore, a must have book
customer_reviews.author: Christine Coombes

customer_reviews.title: Funny book but nothing new to teach
customer_reviews.text: Book is okay. Matt is a knowledgeable weightlifter with lots of experience but this book doesn't contain any more knowledge than Greg Everett's Olympic Weightlifting: A Complete Guide For Athletes and Coaches. Matt's book is a humorous look at weightlifting for the older athlete but if you are an older athlete looking to start training weightlifting seriously, I recommend going with Greg's book.
customer_reviews.author: William Pack

customer_reviews.title: Great read. Definitely lots of insightful info regarding new ...
customer_reviews.text: Great read. Definitely lots of insightful info regarding new lifters, prehab and rehab for persons starting lifting later in life and considering continuing beyond the 'prime years' Additionally gives some solid knowledge on there not being necessarily ' one way to skin a cat.' It is an honest lens into the Weightlifting world, inspirational but also pretty on point. Would recommend the read.
customer_reviews.author: Lady Velez

customer_reviews.title: Geezer Weightlifting!
customer_reviews.text: Matt Foreman's "Olympic Weightlifting for Masters" brings his knowledge, experience and humorous writing style together once again in this inspiring and empowering book. I just started lifting a couple of years ago and I love it, but since I'm in my late 50s, my training needs are not the same as my classmates or even of my coach. This book fills that gap for me, so that I get consistent injury-free gains. My favorite part? The "three cornerstones of geezer weightlifting" -- love it!
customer_reviews.author: Nancy A Colfer DC

customer_reviews.title: Not worth the money
customer_reviews.text: Pretty cookie cutter boring book. Basically, if you get older train less. Wow. Great revelation. Programming is also run of the mill. I regret spending money on this.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Kunde

customer_reviews.title: Great read for older lifters
customer_reviews.text: This book was extremely good and I learned some valuable lessons that I will incorporate into my training. It helped inspire while simultaneously managing expectations of what is possible as an older lifter.
customer_reviews.author: Ann t

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: Felt like I didn't learn much. Was hoping for something a little more concrete.
customer_reviews.author: The Weightlifting Coach

product_meta.title: Olympic Weightlifting for Masters: Training at 30, 40, 50 & Beyond
